message.content:
Research Premiere Pro UXP plugin async/background processing capabilities.

QUESTION TO ANSWER:
What are the limitations of UXP for background processing — can I make async API calls while the user continues editing, or does it block the UI?

For the question provide:
- A direct answer if you find it
- Links to official docs, tutorials, or repos with the answer
- Code examples that illustrate async patterns in UXP

Search for:
- Premiere Pro UXP async API calls
- UXP plugin threading model
- UXP fetch API in Premiere Pro
- UXP background tasks
- Adobe UXP event loop
- UXP plugin performance best practices

Focus on understanding:
- Whether UXP runs in its own thread or shares with Premiere's UI
- How fetch/async operations work in UXP context
- Any documented limitations on long-running operations
- Best practices for non-blocking operations

input.query: Premiere Pro UXP plugin async API calls threading model 2024 2025
Adobe UXP plugin background tasks event loop limitations
UXP fetch API async operations Premiere Pro documentation

Web search results for query: "UXP fetch API async operations Premiere Pro documentation"

Links: [{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Premiere API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Understanding UXP APIs","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/apis/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro"},{"title":"Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Premiere Pro UXP Beta — Blog | Hyper Brew","url":"https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/"},{"title":"Update of UXP APIs inside of Premiere Pro - Premiere Pro - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/update-of-uxp-apis-inside-of-premiere-pro/10384"},{"title":"UXP Arrives in Premiere: A New Era for Plugin Development","url":"https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP fetch API and async operations in Premiere Pro documentation:

## UXP Async Operations in Premiere Pro

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## Key Documentation Resources

Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality. The official documentation website provides documentation for both APIs.

### UXP Core APIs
The UXP platform provides two complementary sets of APIs: UXP Core APIs for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality, and Premiere APIs for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences. Most often, you will need to use both APIs together.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where communication happened through a bridge. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### Accessing UXP APIs
Global APIs are available immediately without any import. Module-based APIs require importing with require(). Permission-based APIs also need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json.

## Current Status
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)For the latest development, ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins. You can download the UDT through Creative Cloud Desktop.

## Official Documentation Links
- Main documentation: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- Understanding UXP APIs: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/apis/
- Sample plugins: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Adobe UXP plugin background tasks event loop limitations"

Links: [{"title":"Adobe","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/develop/plugin-development/xd-concepts/lifecycle/"},{"title":"How to handle the 'Stop' button event when 'plugin is working...'? - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/how-to-handle-the-stop-button-event-when-plugin-is-working/682"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #2 Documentation | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-2-documentation"},{"title":"Known UXP Issues in Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/uxp/known-issues/"},{"title":"Documentation-UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/"},{"title":"API Changelog","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/changelog/"},{"title":"photoshopCore","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/media/photoshopcore/"},{"title":"Plugin lifecycle · Adobe XD Plugin Reference","url":"https://adobexdplatform.com/plugin-docs/reference/core/lifecycle.html?h=panel"},{"title":"Panels and Commands","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/concepts/panels-and-commands/"},{"title":"Photoshop API—UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP plugin background tasks and event loop limitations:

## Key Limitations for Background Tasks in UXP Plugins

### Background Processing Restrictions

"You can also run network requests and timers entirely in the background, outside of any edit operation, though this is discouraged. Plugin code running in the background can make XD slow."(no content)Running network requests and timers in the background is possible but discouraged because plugin code running in the background can make XD slow. Although you'll have read-only access to the scenegraph, this is unsafe since your background code may run in the middle of some other asynchronous edit operation, which means your code might see an incorrect intermediate state of the document.

### Document Editing Restrictions

When a plugin tries to make changes from the background, it throws the error: "Plugin is not permitted to make changes from the background. Return a Promise to continue execution asynchronously."(no content)A key concept in Photoshop UXP plugin development is "execute as modal" - any and all commands that may modify the document, or the application state, must utilize executeAsModal.

### Async/Sync Behavior

An important difference between ExtendScript and UXP in Photoshop is that all ExtendScript calls were synchronous and blocked the Photoshop UI. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.(no content)Just as in a web browser, XD won't update the UI in the middle of your plugin code's synchronous execution. As soon as there's an async gap in execution, any changes you've made to dialog box DOM or to the document scenegraph will be reflected in XD's UI.

### Edit Operation Context

While an edit operation is in progress, XD prevents any edits from other plugins or other features. The user can't interact with any XD UI other than dialogs shown by your plugin. Even if your plugin doesn't have a dialog box open during an async edit operation, the XD UI still remains frozen.

### Plugin Isolation

Each XD document window loads a separate copy of your plugin's JavaScript code with a separate UXP UI document global. It's not yet possible for the JavaScript in one window to communicate with other windows. Each plugin is loaded into an isolated context with its own set of global variables, and different plugins cannot share objects or functions with each other.

### Commands vs Panels

Commands have no lifecycle persistence - they don't stay "running" in the background; they execute when invoked and complete when done.

### Temporary Document for Background Processing

You can create a temporary duplicate document for background processing. This document does not appear in the UI, though there are limitations with some editing features.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

### Background Processing Restrictions

### Async/Sync Behavior

An important difference between ExtendScript and UXP in Photoshop is that all ExtendScript calls were synchronous and blocked the Photoshop UI. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.(no content)Just as in a web browser, XD won't update the UI in the middle of your plugin code's synchronous execution. Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP plugin async API calls and threading model for 2024-2025:

## Key Information

### Threading Model and Async Behavior

"In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited."

### Current Status (2024-2025)

On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro.(no content)UXP has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6, representing a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.

### Architecture Differences from CEP

UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based but built on Adobe's own unique stack, making them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over CEP, where communication happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment.

### API Types

The UXP platform provides two complementary sets of APIs: UXP Core APIs for building user interfaces, file operations, network calls, and general functionality; and Premiere APIs for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences.

### Version Information

Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.(no content)UXP is a JavaScript-based extensibility platform (ES6/ECMAScript 2015 compliant).

### ExtendScript Deprecation Timeline

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Hybrid Plugins Note

UXP has the unique ability of including a C++ Hybrid plugin aspect to run computationally heavy tasks or interact with a host app's C++ APIs directly from the plugin. However, UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Adobe UXP executeAsModal async blocking UI thread Photoshop Premiere"

Links: [{"title":"Modal Execution in an Async World: executeAsModal","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/media/executeasmodal/"},{"title":"Photoshop API—UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/"},{"title":"uxp-photoshop/src/pages/ps_reference/media/executeasmodal.md at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop/blob/main/src/pages/ps_reference/media/executeasmodal.md"},{"title":"photoshopCore","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/media/photoshopcore/"},{"title":"How can we avoid executeASModal progress bar? - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/how-can-we-avoid-executeasmodal-progress-bar/5543"},{"title":"BatchPlay Details","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/media/batchplay/"},{"title":"ExecuteAsModalOptions","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/objects/returnobjects/executeasmodaloptions/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #13 Manifest v5 | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/Adobe-UXP-things-you-need-to-know-manifest-5.html"},{"title":"Bug of the UXP progress bar? Why is the progress bar window never displayed? - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/bug-of-the-uxp-progress-bar-why-is-the-progress-bar-window-never-displayed/5829"},{"title":"Pasing a parameter to photoshop.core.executeAsModal () within a UI component - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/pasing-a-parameter-to-photoshop-core-executeasmodal-within-a-ui-component/4539"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP's `executeAsModal` and its relationship to async operations and the UI thread in Photoshop:

## Key Findings

### executeAsModal Overview
Introduced with apiVersion 2, a modal state is required when a plugin wants to make modifications to the Photoshop state.(no content)This modal state prevents other operations from outside the plugin from interfering, potentially leading to an unstable application state. Operations requiring a modal state include creating or modifying documents, or even updating UI or preference state.

### Async Behavior and UI Thread
In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Using await with executeAsModal
It is highly recommended to use await with calls to executeAsModal. Without an await, execution will proceed to the subsequent lines of code while Photoshop enters the requested modal state.

### How to Access executeAsModal
executeAsModal can be found on the Photoshop UXP API "core" module: `await require('photoshop').core.executeAsModal(targetFunction, options);` where targetFunction is the JavaScript function to execute after Photoshop enters a modal state.

### Blocking Behavior with batchPlay
If set to true, batchPlay will block the entire scripting thread until it resolves, then return the value(s). This is used in the DOM API for property getters and setters, as it allows for simpler code. However, JavaScript code that uses batchPlay directly should avoid using this keyword if possible, and instead use the default form that returns a promise.

### Timeout Issues
mainThreadTimeOutCount tracks the number of JavaScript calls that have timed out. This is typically caused by executing commands while Photoshop is modal without using executeAsModal.

### Modal State Effects
Since only one plugin at a time can use executeAsModal, exclusive access to Photoshop is guaranteed with respect to other plugins' calls to executeAsModal. When executeAsModal is executed, Photoshop enters a modal user interaction state, affecting much of the UI.

**Note:** The search results focused primarily on Photoshop UXP. No specific results were returned for Premiere Pro's implementation of executeAsModal, which may have different behavior or may not use this exact API pattern.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

toolUseResult.query: Adobe UXP executeAsModal async blocking UI thread Photoshop Premiere

Links: [{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #1 Rundown on the UXP announcement | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know"},{"title":"GitHub - adobe/uxp-optimized: Repository for uxp optimized react and javascript components.","url":"https://github.com/adobe/uxp-optimized"},{"title":"Javascript is not single threaded! 🤯 🤩 - DEV Community","url":"https://dev.to/codeparrot/javascript-is-not-single-threaded-5915"},{"title":"Indiscripts :: “Professional Photoshop UXP”","url":"https://indiscripts.com/post/2024/01/professional-photoshop-uxp"},{"title":"Photoshop Plugins With UXP: Introduction | Francesco's GameDev Corner","url":"https://minifloppy.it/posts/2023/photoshop-plugins-with-uxp-introduction/"},{"title":"How to Structure a UXP Plugin for Adobe Indesign","url":"https://www.brad-holmes.co.uk/uxp-plugin-engineering/structuring-a-uxp-plugin/"},{"title":"How to Implement Multi-Threading in Node.js With Worker Threads [Full Handbook]","url":"https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-implement-multi-threading-in-nodejs-with-worker-threads-full-handbook"},{"title":"Single Threaded JavaScript: Top 5 Performance Tips | Code Highlights","url":"https://code-hl.com/javascript/tutorials/single-threaded-javascript"},{"title":"Worker Threads: Javascript is not single threaded!","url":"https://codeparrot.ai/blogs/worker-threads"},{"title":"Is JavaScript Single-Threaded? - Simple Talk","url":"https://www.red-gate.com/simple-talk/development/javascript/javascript-single-threaded/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP (Adobe's Unified Extensibility Platform) and its JavaScript threading model related to plugin performance:

## UXP JavaScript Engine and Threading

UXP plugins have one JavaScript V8 engine alone, and that deals with the scripting side as well now, so we finally got rid of the ExtendScript language.(no content)UXP has one engine compared to the two engines of the CEP system, the one engine deals with both the UI and the scripting side so we have an entirely new scripting engine that has a new DOM.(no content)"UXP's primary strength comes from the single modern JavaScript engine that drives UI logic and scripting capabilities." Regarding the scripts/plugins interface, "UXP takes a more restrained approach (than CEP), prioritising performance over a Standard feature set."

## Performance Characteristics

The UI is not just shown as rendered HTML elements in the user interface, instead it is parsed and then converted into native controls. So your HTML button is not just displayed as CEP would do, but it is converted into a native bit of Photoshop UI, made of the same matter of all the rest of the native Photoshop UI. And this speeds up the whole interface quite a bit, solving both CEP's main problems at once: the two engines and the reactivity of the interface / the footprint it has in your system.(no content)UXP uses web technologies to create custom UI. Rendering is handled via a custom engine that promises better performance over the Chromium Embedded Framework used by CEP.(no content)The JavaScript side of UXP is powered by the Chromium V8 engine, which means all modern JavaScript features — such as Promises, async/await, lambas, modules, destructuring, etc. — are supported out-of-the-box. WebAssembly is supported as well.

## Asynchronous Programming in UXP

JavaScript (and therefore UXP) now favors asynchronous programming with Promises, "simplifying the handling of non-blocking tasks that call for the host application's complete attention".

## Native Code Option for Performance-Intensive Tasks

This is different from what's possible with CEP + CSDK (or even UXP + CSDK) in that the C++ code is distributed with and runs alongside the JavaScript code. Communication between the two happens via an API layer modeled against NodeJS N-API. It should be possible to use native C++ code for performance-intensive tasks such as image processing (i.e. normalizing a normal map, inverting its channels, etc.), making it an interesting option for game dev.

## UXP Performance Optimization Tips

Adobe provides an official library for optimizing UXP plugins:

Uxp Optimized is a library of browser compatible react components specifically optimized for Adobe's Unified Extensibility Platform. It includes a react virtualizer for efficiently rendering long lists of items.

Key optimization recommendations include:
- Minimize number of elements rendered per virtual item. All virtual items with the same html structure should share the same "itemType". Items are only recycled within the same "itemType".
- Prefer to use display: none; instead of visibility: hidden; for invisible elements. display: none means native elements don't have to be created. We don't want to pay a cost for elements that only might become visible.

## Module System Limitations

Adobe's UXP runtime doesn't support imports, modules, or component files. Everything has to live inside one main.js. This is an important consideration for plugin structure and performance optimization.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

# UXP Premiere Pro Async/Await Code Examples

Based on the repository content provided, I cannot find specific code examples demonstrating async/await, fetch API, network calls, or background processing patterns in this UXP Premiere Pro plugins repository.

The README indicates the repository contains:
- A sample panel plugin in the `sample-panels/premiere-api/html` directory
- TypeScript definition files for IDE support
- A transcript JSON definition file

However, the actual source code files aren't included in the web page content you provided. To locate these patterns, you would need to:

1. **Examine the sample plugin source** in `sample-panels/premiere-api/html/` on GitHub directly
2. **Review the official documentation** at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ for API patterns
3. **Check the GitHub repository's code files** rather than just the overview page

The page confirms TypeScript support is available, which would facilitate async/await usage, but specific implementation examples aren't visible in this excerpt.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP plugin setTimeout/setInterval timer background usage in Adobe:

## Key Findings

### setTimeout in UXP
The `setTimeout` function creates a request to call a callback after delta milliseconds. The request is cancelable using the return ID, which returns a Timer ID.

### Historical Context
The dev team was working on implementing setTimeout in UXP, and developers needed workarounds for getting regular callbacks to their applications for debugging purposes.(no content)Developers had loops that froze the UI for seconds and asked for alternatives until setTimeout and setInterval became available.

### Running Timers in Background
You can run network requests and timers entirely in the background, outside of any edit operation, though this is discouraged. Plugin code running in the background can make XD slow. Additionally, while you'll have read-only access to the scenegraph, this is unsafe since your background code may run in the middle of some other asynchronous edit operation, meaning your code might see an incorrect intermediate state of the document.

### Using setInterval for Selection Checking
One developer started using setInterval() to check selection instead of relying on selection changes. This adjustment seemed to work well on Mac, though there was no definite way to replicate certain behaviors to confirm it fixed all original issues.

### ExtendScript Limitations (Older Technology)
Adobe omitted common timers and intervals from the internal JavaScript in ExtendScript. setInterval and setTimeout would be useful but were missing, alongside mouse events - both of which would open up new possibilities.

### About UXP
UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) was first introduced into Adobe XD in 2018 as Adobe's answer to a more modern extensibility engine. UXP is now integrated into XD, Photoshop, and InDesign.(no content)UXP is the modern way to create plugins and scripts for Adobe Creative Cloud. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine, offers a curated selection of UI components and a more streamlined workflow for developers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP plugin setTimeout/setInterval timer background usage in Adobe:

## Key Findings

### setTimeout in UXP
The `setTimeout` function creates a request to call a callback after delta milliseconds. The request is cancelable using the return ID, which returns a Timer ID.

### Historical Context
The dev team was working on implementing setTimeout in UXP, and developers needed workarounds for getting regular callbacks to their applications for debugging purposes.(no content)Developers had loops that froze the UI for seconds and asked for alternatives until setTimeout and setInterval became available.

### Running Timers in Background
You can run network requests and timers entirely in the background, outside of any edit operation, though this is discouraged. Plugin code running in the background can make XD slow. Additionally, while you'll have read-only access to the scenegraph, this is unsafe since your background code may run in the middle of some other asynchronous edit operation, meaning your code might see an incorrect intermediate state of the document.

### Using setInterval for Selection Checking
One developer started using setInterval() to check selection instead of relying on selection changes. This adjustment seemed to work well on Mac, though there was no definite way to replicate certain behaviors to confirm it fixed all original issues.

### ExtendScript Limitations (Older Technology)
Adobe omitted common timers and intervals from the internal JavaScript in ExtendScript. setInterval and setTimeout would be useful but were missing, alongside mouse events - both of which would open up new possibilities.

### About UXP
UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) was first introduced into Adobe XD in 2018 as Adobe's answer to a more modern extensibility engine. UXP is now integrated into XD, Photoshop, and InDesign.(no content)UXP is the modern way to create plugins and scripts for Adobe Creative Cloud. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine, offers a curated selection of UI components and a more streamlined workflow for developers.

Web search results for query: ""UXP" "does not block" OR "non-blocking" UI JavaScript execution Adobe"

Links: [{"title":"Photoshop API—UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/"},{"title":"Getting Started—UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/guides/"},{"title":"Indiscripts :: “Professional Photoshop UXP”","url":"https://indiscripts.com/post/2024/01/professional-photoshop-uxp"},{"title":"Solved: UXP modeless dialog - Adobe Product Community - 13394024","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/indesign-discussions/uxp-modeless-dialog/td-p/13394024"},{"title":"Let’s stop labelling asynchronous JavaScript as non-blocking! - Fasterize","url":"https://www.fasterize.com/en/blog/lets-stop-labelling-asynchronous-javascript-as-non-blocking/"},{"title":"What is a non-blocking script? - Human Who Codes","url":"https://humanwhocodes.com/blog/2010/08/10/what-is-a-non-blocking-script/"},{"title":"Stop Getting In My Way! — Non-blocking UX | by Sophie Paxton | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@sophie_paxtonUX/stop-getting-in-my-way-non-blocking-ux-5cbbfe0f0158"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP's non-blocking behavior for UI and JavaScript execution in Adobe applications:

## Key Findings

### UXP's Non-Blocking Architecture

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### UXP Plugins Run in Non-Blocking Threads

Unlike older CEP (Common Extensibility Platform) plugins, UXP plugins run within the same process as the host application, with their UI in its own non-blocking thread. Also unlike CEP plugins, UXP plugins communicate natively with the host application; there is no boundary between JavaScript and ExtendScript that requires passing strings back and forth.

### Modern JavaScript and Asynchronous Programming

The JavaScript engine is V8, a modern implementation used in many popular browsers. This is in contrast to the engine used in ExtendScript, which is ECMA Edition 3 (about 20 years old). UXP supports all of ES5 and most of ES6 features, including arrow functions, async/await, etc.(no content)JavaScript (and therefore UXP) now favors asynchronous programming with Promises, "simplifying the handling of non-blocking tasks that call for the host application's" completion.

### Non-Blocking Dialogs in UXP

For non-blocking dialogs, users can create a dialog and call show() instead of showModal(). So far this seems to work.(no content)Some users also needed to add fake sleep using setTimeout() to allow the UI to update.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP's non-blocking behavior for UI and JavaScript execution in Adobe applications:

## Key Findings

### UXP's Non-Blocking Architecture

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### UXP Plugins Run in Non-Blocking Threads

Unlike older CEP (Common Extensibility Platform) plugins, UXP plugins run within the same process as the host application, with their UI in its own non-blocking thread. Also unlike CEP plugins, UXP plugins communicate natively with the host application; there is no boundary between JavaScript and ExtendScript that requires passing strings back and forth.

### Modern JavaScript and Asynchronous Programming

The JavaScript engine is V8, a modern implementation used in many popular browsers. This is in contrast to the engine used in ExtendScript, which is ECMA Edition 3 (about 20 years old). UXP supports all of ES5 and most of ES6 features, including arrow functions, async/await, etc.(no content)JavaScript (and therefore UXP) now favors asynchronous programming with Promises, "simplifying the handling of non-blocking tasks that call for the host application's" completion.

### Non-Blocking Dialogs in UXP

For non-blocking dialogs, users can create a dialog and call show() instead of showModal(). So far this seems to work.(no content)Some users also needed to add fake sleep using setTimeout() to allow the UI to update.

Links: [{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Premiere API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/"},{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro-samples/README.md at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"Premiere Pro panels - Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/ReadMe.md"},{"title":"[UXP for Premiere Pro 25.0+] How to get the active project object? app.project is always undefined.","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/uxp-for-premiere-pro-25-0-how-to-get-the-active-project-object-app-project-is-always-undefined/m-p/15512292"},{"title":"UXP Arrives in Premiere: A New Era for Plugin Development","url":"https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development"}]

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP plugin development with fetch API and async code examples:

## Premiere Pro UXP Plugin Resources

### Official Sample Repository
The Adobe third-party sample panel is available in the premiere-api directory from the Git repository at https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples. The plugin is built in the /build-html directory.(no content)You can see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code. Adobe has included Premiere Pro's transcript JSON definition in the assets directory within the premiere-api sample plugin.

### Async/Await API Behavior
An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread.(no content)For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited. It is worth noting that they are, in the background, asynchronous in nature.

### Getting Started
Before you start, make sure you have Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.

### Key Resources
- **Official Documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **Sample Plugins GitHub**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples
- UXP provides file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality.(no content)As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which Adobe will remove support for CEP extensibility.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
